{{Orphan|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox artist | honorific_prefix = | name = Alicia Craig Faxon | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1931 | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = | education = BA [[Vassar College]] (1952)
MA [[Radcliffe College]] (1953)
PhD [[Boston University]] (1979) | alma_mater = | known_for = Author, art historian, professor, curator | notable_works = Dante Gabriel Rossetti
Self-Portraits by Women Painters
Pre-Raphaelite Art in its European Context | style = | movement = | spouse = Richard Bremmer Faxon | awards = [[Women's Caucus for Art Lifetime Achievement Award]] | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = | module = }} '''Alicia Craig Faxon''' is an art historian, author, curator and educator. She is Professor Emerita [[Simmons College]], where she also served as Chair of the Department of Art and Music. Saxon also taught at [[Harvard University]], the [[New England School of Art]] and the [[Massachusetts College of Art]]. She has curated several museum exhibitions, and served as acting director of the [[Danforth Museum]] in Framingham, MA. She authored several books on art history, as well as writing for the popular press, including the Boston Globe. Her archive and papers (ca. 1969–2014) are held in the collection of Vassar University Special Collections Library.{{cite web|title=Guide to the Alicia Craig Faxon Papers, ca. 1969-2014|url=http://specialcollections.vassar.edu/collections/manuscripts/findingaids/faxon_alicia_craig.html|website=Archives and Special Collections Library|publisher=Vassar College|accessdate=19 January 2017}} ==Publications== Faxon has authored several books including ''Dante Gabriel Rossetti'', Abbeville Press, that was reviewed in Publishers Weekly and Cosmopolitan.{{cite book|last1=Faxon|first1=Alicia Craig|title=Dante Gabriel Rossetti|date=1989|publisher=Abbeville Press|isbn=978-0-89659-928-4|url=https://www.abbeville.com/books/dante-gabriel-rossetti-by-alicia-craig-faxon-128-b|accessdate=19 January 2017}}{{cite journal|title=Dante Gabriel Rossetti Alicia Craig Faxon, Author|journal=Publishers Weekly|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-89659-928-4|accessdate=19 January 2017}} Other books include ''Self-Portraits by Women Painters'' (coauthored with Liana Cheney, and Kathleen Russo), published by Ashgate Press in 2000, and ''Pre-Raphaelite Art in its European Context'', and ''Women and Jesus''.{{cite book|last1=Faxon|first1=Alicia Craig|title=Women and Jesus|date=1973|publisher=Harper Collins|isbn=9780829802443|url=http://www.biblio.com/women-and-jesus-by-faxon-alicia-craig/work/3250640|accessdate=19 January 2017}} She contributed several entries to the ''Encyclopedia of Comparative Iconography: Themes Depicted in Works of Art'', including entries on Fatal Woman/Femme Fatale, Hair/Haircutting, Kiss/Kissing, Sacrifice, Martyrdom, Temptation, Metamorphosis and others.{{cite book|last1=Roberts|first1=Helene R.|title=Encyclopedia of Comparative Iconography: Themes Depicted in Works of Art|date=2013|publisher=Routledge, Taylor & Francis|isbn=9781136787935|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rMeJDwmr_hcC&pg=PR12&lpg=PR12&dq=alicia+craig+faxon&source=bl&ots=-vG5OlyWzl&sig=teDXNMaOxCSM1ocKnvhJFs8T8v4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiE0eTUqM3RAhXD4iYKHUERC0I4ChDoAQgmMAM#v=onepage&q=alicia%20craig%20faxon&f=false|accessdate=19 January 2017}} ==Awards and honors== Saxon has received honors and awards for her work including the [[Women's Caucus for Art Lifetime Achievement Award]] in 1996, and a publication in her honor, BREAKING NEW GROUND IN ART HISTORY: A Festschrift in Honor of Alicia Craig Faxon, edited by Margaret A. Hanni.{{cite book|last1=Hanni, ed.|first1=Margaret A.|title=BREAKING NEW GROUND IN ART HISTORY: A Festschrift in Honor of Alicia Craig Faxon|date=2014|publisher=New Academia Publishing|isbn=978-0-9915047-4-9|url=http://www.newacademia.com/academic-books/art-history-policies/breaking-new-ground-in-art-history-a-festschrift-in-honor-of-alicia-craig-faxon/|accessdate=19 January 2017}}{{cite web|title=Past Honor Award Recipients|url=https://www.nationalwca.org/awards/pasthonorees.php|website=nationalwca.org|publisher=Women's Caucus for Art|accessdate=19 January 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Faxon, Alicia}} [[Category:American art historians]] [[Category:Women art historians]] [[Category:American women educators]] [[Category:1931 births]] [[Category:Radcliffe College alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Vassar College alumni]] [[Category:Boston University alumni]] [[Category:American women non-fiction writers]]

'''Applied Education''' is a school for [[bookkeeper]]s and [[Tax agency|tax agents]]<ref>{{cite web|title=BAS Agent TPB Education Requirements|url=https://www.appliededucation.edu.au/bookkeeping-accounting/tax-practitioner-board-licensing-units|website=Applied Education}}</ref> approved by the Tax Practitioners Board<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tpb.gov.au/TPB/Qualifications_and_experience/TPB/Qualifications_and_experience/0571_Australian_taxation_law_qualifications_list.aspx|title=Approved course providers|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> and [[Institute of Certified Bookkeepers]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.icb.org.au/Professional-Development/Accredited-Training-Providers|title=Accredited Training Providers - ICB|website=www.icb.org.au|access-date=2016-03-12}}</ref>
The [[Government of Australia|Australian Government]] created legislation called the Tax Agent Services Act 2009 (TASA)<ref>[https://www.legislation.gov.au/Series/C2009A00013 Tax Agent Services Act 2009 (TASA)]</ref> to ensure that people preparing Business Activity Statements for a fee are registered. The Tax Practitioners Board<ref>[http://www.tpb.gov.au Tax Practitioners Board]</ref> administers and manages the registration of bookkeepers in Australia. Prior to this anyone could act as a bookkeeper and this created concern that business were getting poor advice from unqualified people.
Applied Education is a [[Registered training organisation|Registered Training Organisation]], which commenced in 1999.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://training.gov.au/Organisation/Details/52240|title=training.gov.au - 52240 - Applied Education|website=training.gov.au|access-date=2016-03-12}}</ref>
website - [https://Www.appliededucation.edu.au www.appliededucation.edu.au]

{{color box|#4169E1}} |image_name = BAULogo.png |staff=313 |faculty=1000 }} '''Beirut Arab University (BAU)''' ({{lang-ar|جـامعة بيروت العربية}}) is a Lebanese [[private university|private]] university located in [[Beirut]], [[Lebanon]]. It was founded by the Lebanese El-Bir and Ihsan Society in 1960.{{cite web|author=Charbel Nahas|title=Financing Higher Education in Lebanon|url=http://www.erf.org.eg/CMS/uploads/pdf/1245581590_FinancingHigherEducation_Lebanon.pdf|work=Economic Research Forum|accessdate=15 July 2014|date=April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140716091309/http://www.erf.org.eg/CMS/uploads/pdf/1245581590_FinancingHigherEducation_Lebanon.pdf|archivedate=16 July 2014|df=}} The university is ranked among the top universities in the [[Arab world|Arab Region]] by 2015/16 [[QS World University Rankings]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/arab-region-university-rankings/2015#sorting=rank+region=+country=+faculty=+stars=false+search=|title=QS Arab Region ranking|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} Beirut Arab University is a member of: *[[Association of Arab Universities]] (AARU) *[[International Association of Universities]] (IAU) *[[Federation of the Universities of the Islamic World]] (FUIW) *[[Agence Universitaire de la Francophonie]] (AUF): *Conférence des Recteurs de la Région du Moyen-Orient(CONFREMO) *Réseau International Francophone des établissements de formation de formateurs (RIFEFF) *[[Ecole Doctorale de Droit du Moyen- Orient (EDDMO)]] *Collège Doctoral de Français au Moyen Orient (CODFRAMO) *[[International Association of University Presidents]] (IAUP) *Association of Universities of Lebanon *Euro- Mediterranean University (EMUNI) *Euromed Permanent University Forum (EPUF) *[[International Council for Open and Distance Education]](ICDE) *[[International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions]](IFLA) *Arab Association of Collegiate Registrars& Admissions Officers ( ARAB-ACRAO) *Association of the Arab Faculties of Dentistry (Affiliated to AARU) *Scientific Association of Colleges of Pharmacy in the Arab World (Affiliated to AARU) *Arab Society of Faculties of Business Administration (Affiliated to AARU) *[[Union of International Associations]] (UIA) *Scientific Society of Arab Nursing Faculties (Affiliated to AARU) *Islamic Universities League *[[United Nations Global Compact]] *Association for Dental Education in Europe (ADEE) *[[Arab Forum for Environment and Development]] (AFED) *Lebanese Academic Library Consortium (LALC) *European Foundation for Management and Development (EFMD) ==Faculties== The University currently consists of the following 10 faculties: *Faculty of Arts *Faculty of Law & Political Science *Faculty of Business Administration *Faculty of Architectural Engineering *Faculty of Engineering *Faculty of Science *Faculty of Pharmacy *Faculty of Medicine *Faculty of Dentistry *Faculty of Health Sciences ==Campuses== '''Beirut Campus:'''
It is the main campus located at the south gate of the capital Beirut, specifically in Tarik El-Jadidah District, and houses the following faculties: Arts, Law & Political Science, Commerce & Business Administration, Pharmacy, Medicine, Dentistry and Health Sciences. Beirut campus is undergoing continuous renovation and renewal of its buildings. [[File:BAU Beirut Campus.jpg|thumb|Beirut campus with a view of the Hariri Building.{{Cite web|url=https://iconnect.bau.edu.lb/bau_content/mssfront/kdn-images/gallery-3.jpg|title=BAU Iconnect|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}|378x378px]] '''Debbieh Campus:'''
First- Location - BAU’s land is located on the real estate number 615 in Debbieh, and it is 33 km far from Beirut Campus. The land has an area of 693,000 m2. The highest point there is 404 m above sea level, while the lowest point is 154 m above sea level. The land encompasses 4 hills each of which is known for its height or function. '''Tripoli Campus:'''
BAU’s campus is located in Debeya area next to the Olympic Stadium. It is 88 km far from BAU’s Campus in Beirut.The land was bought on 13/12/2003. It has an area of 15,540 m 2 and is distinguished by its view overlooking the sea with a frontage of 185 m long. It is located on two main roads which makes it easy to get to the university. ==BAU Student Prospectus== *Governing bodies: University Higher Council; University Council *Academic year: September to June *Admission requirements: To be accepted for an undergraduate degree, applicants must: **Hold the official Lebanese Secondary School Certificate in a branch relevant to the chosen undergraduate field of specialization, or an official equivalent; **Pass the relevant admission examinations *Tuition Fees The cost of each credit hour is determined by the university administration and fees vary depending on the faculty. *Main language of instruction: Arabic, English, French == English Language Requirements == All programs and examinations at BAU are set in English except for the Faculties of Arts and Law where the language of instruction varies depending on the nature of the course/s. Hence, applicants must provide evidence of their English language proficiency in one of the following ways: All undergraduate applicants and transferring students are expected to pass BAU's English Language admission exam with a minimum score of 70%. However, applicants who have passed a TOEFL Exam with a minimum score of 500 or IELTS with a minimum score of 6.5 or have successfully completed the General Certificate of Education (GCE) program are exempted from this English Language admission exam. Similarly, transferring students who have completed a minimum of two years at an institution where the language of instruction is English are exempted from BAU's English Language admission exam. == Financial Aid and Scholarships == BAU provides direct financial support to students experiencing hardship in the form of tuition fees deductions. '''Undergraduate Program Scholarships''' *BAU offers 4 scholarships annually. These scholarships are available to first year students who rank in the top ten positions in the four branches of the Lebanese Secondary School Certificate. These students can also benefit from these scholarships during their undergraduate study as long as they get a CGPA of 3.33 or above. *Three scholarships are offered to the first three BAU students in each of the departments of the Faculty they are registered in provided that they get a SGPA of 3.00 and above at the end of each semester, with not less than 15 credits per semester. Each semester, a maximum of 5 top students, at each level of all undergraduate programs, who have completed 15 credits and above and have not failed any course during the same semester, are exempted from a percentage of the subsequent semester tuition fees as follows: 1st place: 80% 2nd place: 50% 3rd place: 30% 4th place: 25% 5th place 15% '''Prizes''' *President's Honor List and Dean's Honor list: Students with a SGPA of 3.8 or above are included on the President's Honor list and those with a SGPA of 3.5 or above are included on the Dean's Honor list. *Gamal Abdel Nasser Award A student in the undergraduate level is granted Gamal Abdel Nasser Award for Academic Distinction provided that his grade is not less than "Very Good" == Housing == [[File:BAU housing.jpg|thumb|231x231px]] '''Beirut Campus:''' Housing is not available on Beirut Campus; however, the city of Beirut offers various furnished and non-furnished apartments at reasonable prices. '''Debbieh Campus:''' The students' accommodation building consists of three levels with a total of 66 rooms, each having its private bathroom. The rooms are fully furnished with built-in closets, beds, and study desks. A new student accommodation building is also under construction, with a total area of 7,000 square meters to eventually house 133 students. Ten single rooms will have private toilets, while 60 single rooms and 21 triple rooms will share common services. The building will provide its residents with a reception area, lounges, study rooms, TV hall and gymnasium. == Notable alumni == *Prime Minister [[Rafik Al-Hariri]] of Lebanon *Prime Minister [[Abdullah bin Nasser bin Khalifa Al Thani]] of [[Qatar]] *Deputy Prime Minister [[Tawfiq Kreishan]] of Jordan *Minister of Interior [[Eid Al-Fayez]] of Jordan *Ministry for Foreign Affairs [[Mohammed Hussein Al Shaali]] of United Arab Emirates *Former Governor of Jerusalem [[Jamil Othman Nasser]] of Palestine *Palestinian Jurist [[Hilmi M. Zawati]] * [[Shalimar Sharbatly]], abstract artist == ''Al-Zamil'' Magazine == ''Al Zamil'' is an academic, cultural, social periodical published by Beirut Arab University. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.bau.edu.lb/ Beirut Arab University]—{{en icon}}—{{ar icon}} *[http://www.bau-alumni.org BAU alumni] *[http://www.4icu.org/reviews/3154.htm Web Ranking of Beirut Arab University] {{coord|33.8733|35.4969|region:LB_type:edu|display=title}} [[Category:Beirut Arab University| ]] [[Category:Education in Beirut]] [[Category:Schools in Beirut]] [[Category:Universities in Lebanon]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1960]] [[Category:1960 establishments in Lebanon]]

'''Bishnupur High School''' is a co-educational school located in [[Balasore]], [[Odisha]]. It is one of the oldest and top-ranked high schools in the district and the first in [[Bahanaga]].<ref name=board/> It is a [[Government School|public]] [[Mixed-sex education|co-educational]] institution located at Bishnupur Gram Panchayat.
It has more than two thousand students. The school offers grades from class IIIX to class X. It has two shifts, morning and day. The morning shift starts at 10:00 am and the day shift runs from 12:00 pm to 4:00 pm.
Beside the school playground, Bishnupur High School owns the Bishnupur Melana Padia (ବିଷନୁପୁର ମେଲନ ପଡ଼ିଆ). The school celebrated its 46th anniversary on 23-03 March 2017.
== History == <!-- [[File:Bishnupur High School Campus.jpg|thumb|left|Barisal Zilla School is one of the oldest educational institution in East side of Odisha]] --> The school was founded by Englishman Mr. Panda on 23 March 1971, with 8 students.
It was the first high school in Bahanaga Block. The then name of the school was "Baniha Uchha Bidyalaya". Panda became the first Headmaster.
This school opened under Government management as Bishnupur High School. In 1971, it was declared to be a government school and was renamed 'Bishnupur High School'. At that time, the school building was on Mr. Panda's land at the north side of the Bishnupur Market and Hospital.<ref name="board">{{cite web|title=Board Of Secondary Education|url=http://www.bseodisha.nic.in|website=www.bseodisha.nic.in|accessdate=24 November 2017}}</ref>
<!-- == Gallery== <gallery mode=packed> Bishnupur High School Main Building.jpg Bishnupur High School (2).jpg Bishnupur High School (4).jpg Bishnupur High School (3).jpg </gallery> -->

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} [[Image:Bommersvik.png|thumb|right|Bommersvik Logo]] '''Bommersvik''' is a '''Union college''' ({{lang-sv|italic=yes|Förbundskola}} from Förbund meaning ''union'' or ''association'' and skola meaning ''school'' or ''college'') built by the [[Swedish Social Democratic Youth League]] (SSU) and is situated outside the municipality of [[Södertälje]] in Sweden. Parts of the college grounds encompass a [[conference centre]] and recreational facilities that are extensively used by social democratic organizations both in Sweden and abroad. An art gallery can also be found on the grounds.
==Mission== [[Image:Per Albin Hansson föreläser Bommersvik.JPG|thumb|350px|[[Per Albin Hansson]] (Prime Minister of Sweden from 1932 to 1946) delivering an outdoor lecture on Bommersvik grounds. Summer 1940]] The college was formed because the SSU and the [[Swedish Social Democratic Party]] planned to educate and train the next generation of trade union and [[Politician|political leaders]] by establishing an institution of higher learning with the mission to instruct these young social democrats on political matters such as trade union agreements and laws. Today it offers many popular courses each year on political science subjects. The curriculum is different from a regular [[political science]] academy in that the content of the courses is primarily focused on issues concerning the politics of the [[labour movement]].
The backgrounds of the professors teaching at the college vary and, depending on the course, lecturers can be recruited from the party and from the unions and labour movement. It is not uncommon for prime ministers or cabinet ministers to lecture on subjects of political interest. The Swedish Prime Minister [[Per Albin Hansson]] lectured at Bommersvik as early as summer 1940.
Many foreign lecturers also visit the college from time to time, starting with the early example of [[Willy Brandt]] who lectured on 1 December 1940 about the problems experienced by the [[social democrats]] in [[Nazi]] Germany and the occupied countries at the start of [[World War II]].
In 2010, the college began cooperating with [[Uppsala University]] so that students from the University can now attend [[rhetoric]] classes at Bommersvik.
==History== [[Image:Bommersvik flaggor.JPG|thumb|right|200px|left|Colonel Lundeberg extracted a promise from the SSU that the [[Swedish flag]] would always be raised higher than the SSU [[Banner#Trade union banners|banner]]. This promise has been kept by the SSU ever since.]] In 1934, ideas about creating a college for the Youth League began to form after Ivan Ohlson, one of the great leaders of the Swedish Labor movement, became inspired following a study trip to the [[Netherlands]] and [[Belgium]] and in 1936 work commenced to find an appropriate building. This was familiar territory for the SSU since the association already had gone through a similar process with another school, the Brunnsviks adult education college in Ludvika. Ivan Ohlson went on a late summer day to Bommersvik, with its beautiful natural surroundings, was sufficiently impressed with the place and recommended it as the future location for the school. His recommendation was officially adopted and in 1937 the decision was formalised. Ivan Ohlson is considered to be the founder of Bommersvik and one of the school's halls is named in his honour.
It was decided, after a search, that the school would be built on the grounds of a local farm. This property was owned by [[Colonel]] Lundeberg.
Only through a fundraising drive among the members and other organisations within the [[Labor Movement]], including the social democratic women's association, the party and trade unions etc. could the Socialist Party and the SSU find sufficient funds to buy Colonel Lundeberg's farm. The colonel, however, thought that selling the farm directly to the SSU was a sensitive matter, (since he was a military man with no association with the socialists), so, officially, Ivan Ohlson bought the farm instead, for 127,000 sek and a down payment of 20 000 which was a lot of money at that time. Colonel Lundeberg also extracted a promise from the SSU that the [[Swedish flag]] would always be raised higher than the SSU [[Banner#Trade union banners|banner]]. This promise has been kept by the SSU ever since.
The opening ceremony was held on 14 September 1937 with about 800 SSU members and party officials on the grounds. There was also high pressure on the officials involved because, among other things, of the press coverage of the event and of the political pressure by the social democrats. Algot Andersson became the first manager of the college.
Another important event took place when [[Tage Erlander]] withdrew in 1969 as party leader and Prime Minister, and his successor in both positions, [[Olof Palme]], ordered an honorary residence be built for him on the grounds of Bommersvik, in recognition of Erlander's valuable and lengthy service as Prime Minister of Sweden. The house is called even to this day "Erlandervillan" meaning ''Erlander's villa''. There, he and his wife Aina lived until his death in 1985.
==Culture and art== [[Image:The Utøya-monument at Bommersvik (14658741627).jpg|thumb|Monument on Bommersvik of Victims of Utoya massacre in 2011.]] [[Image:Olof Palme statsminister, tidigt 70-tal.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Olof Palme]] (pictured) donated the majority of the vases from the Ming Dynasty]] Social democratic Prime Ministers have brought, from time to time, [[work of art|objets d'art]] and other curios on their travels to the college in order to enhance its culture and [[fine art|art]] collections. For example, [[Olof Palme]] has donated to the school the majority of the vases from the [[Ming Dynasty]], the stuffed remains of a tiger and a gold statue of an [[Inca]] god. Various countries have also donated items for the school's collection. Perhaps the most controversial present was from [[North Vietnam]], namely the part of an American airplane shot down during the [[Vietnam war]]. This piece exists as a display case exhibit at the school.
In the college, students learn about [[criticism]] of society and there also exist pictures of famous artists that created fine portraits of well-known social democrats. There is a large library with books about policy and from authors that describe the workers' lives in Sweden, the so-called ''proletärförfattare,'' ([[Swedish language|Swedish]]:'' proletär'' meaning ''[[proletarian]]'' and ''författare'' meaning ''author,'' i.e. authors for the [[proletariat]]), such as [[Eyvind Johnson]] and [[Harry Martinson]] who shared the [[Nobel Prize in Literature]] in 1974.
===Significant art exhibits=== * One of the most well-known sculptures in Bommersvik is Arne Jones's "Katedralen" (''Cathedral''), also featured on Bommervik's logo.<ref name="Katedralen picture">[http://www.bommersvik.se/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=29&Itemid=60 Katedralen picture from the Bommersvik website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070622062241/http://www.bommersvik.se/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=29&Itemid=60 |date=22 June 2007 }}</ref> * "Torchlight processions", depicting the infamous [[Triumph of the Will|Nazi torchlight marches]], by artist Eric Johnsson. SSU received this as a present in 1937 as an indication of gratitude. Eric had among other things been forced to escape from [[Nazi Germany]]. SSU had criticized the [[Nazis]] in Germany long before the parent party did so in public. [[Image:Bommersvik.JPG|thumb|right|260px|Bommersvik's main building: the Manor]] * Tage Erlander and his legacy have always been important to the school and there are many portraits of him by artists such as Bo Beskow, Stig Claesson and Willem de Geer. * The large oil painting "Proletarian fighting will" (Swedish: ''Proletär kampvilja'' the latter from ''kamp'' meaning ''fight'' and ''vilja'' meaning ''will'') by Albin Amelin that hangs in the dining room is also a gift. The Amelin family wanted it to be displayed in a prominent place where many socialist supporters and members could view it. * A copy of Carl Elds' sculpture “[[Youth]]” is exhibited while the original is left in the National museum. * Folke Allards' [[aquarelle]] "Bommersvik i sommarskrud" (translated as: ''Bommersvik in summer clothes'') is also a gift. * “Light and mood” by [[Gösta Werner (painter)]] is an [[abstract painting]] and an attempt to expand artistic horizons and to depart from the tradition of [[socialist realism]]. * Sculptor [[Willy Gordon]] created "The meeting" in [[Scale model|miniature]] and the original exists in [[Östermalmstorg]] in Stockholm. ''The meeting,'' ({{lang-sv|Mötet}}), is a controversial group of two modern sculptures representing a naked male figure bearing a piece of meat on his shoulders before a recumbent female figure. * Ely Maoz, a well-known artist from [[Chile]], painted a picture that hangs on a wall of the wing together with some SSU members' paintings. The painting is called "Freedom for all and Peace for the whole world". It was given to the school as a gesture of appreciation since the SSU criticized the [[Augusto Pinochet|dictatorship in Chile]].
==Symbolic value== [[Image:Tage Erlander, Bommersvik 1948.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Tage Erlander]] ( Prime Minister of Sweden from 1946 to 1969.) dictating a letter to his secretary Maria Nyström in the natural surroundings of Bommersvik. Summer 1948.]] Bommersvik possesses symbolic value for social democrats worldwide, and has become something of a socialist [[Mecca]] for them. This is also true for those who choose to tie the knot in Bommersvik. For example, two famous locals, Roger Möller and Gerd married there in 1978. Roger Möller later went on to become manager of the school. Many high echelon social democratic party officials have traditionally visited the place and many important meetings were scheduled in Bommersvik. Decisions such as, for example about ATP, have been discussed and analyzed at Bommersvik.
Bommersvik is a place that is a [[sanctuary]] and a source of inspiration for many, while also providing a recreation haven for social democrats. SSU member Lotta Axelsson described Bommersvik this way: ''Bommersvik inspires new ideas, and provides possibilities for recreation and strolling in a natural setting and for rest. There is actually little discussion about socialist issues during leisure activities, as visitors long for going back to nature.''
Social democrat [[Member of Parliament|parliamentarians]] and government ministers come to Bommersvik when they need inspiration. For example, [[Ingvar Carlsson]] went to Bommersvik after the assassination of [[Olof Palme]] in order to relax there before presenting his new cabinet and the [[speech from the throne]].
==International conferences== After the “[[Milan]]” building with its [[:wikt:conference|conference]] and lecture halls and interpreter facilities was completed in 1978 it was natural that the [[Socialist International]] organisation would now book conferences for Bommersvik.<ref name="Milan pictures">[http://www.bommersvik.se/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=38&Itemid=68 Milan pictures from the Bommersvik website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070828004622/http://www.bommersvik.se/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=38&Itemid=68 |date=28 August 2007 }}</ref> The Milan building and its facilities were inaugurated during the European Labor movement's conference in 1979, with a return engagement in 1985. Both conferences were convened by Palme, the Social Democratic Party leader. Many famous social democrats from other countries have visited Bommersvik through the years, including [[Shimon Peres]], [[Neil Kinnock]], [[Willy Brandt]], [[Trygve Bratteli]], [[Poul Nyrup Rasmussen]], [[Kalevi Sorsa]], [[Mário Soares]], [[François Mitterrand]] and [[Bruno Kreisky]]. In addition, many other international conferences have also been held there, such as, for example, the [[International Union of Socialist Youth#IUSY Congresses|1989 congress]] of the [[International Union of Socialist Youth]] and the 2003 congress of the European Community Organisation of Socialist Youth ([[ECOSY]]). Anders Lindberg became the first Swedish president of ECOSY when he was elected by this congress.
==The Bommersvik Declarations== Bommersvik played a central role in [[international politics]] in 1995 and 2002 when the two conventions of the Elected [[Legislature|Representatives]] of the [[Myanmar|Union of Burma]] took place and the following two landmark declarations were issued:<ref name="Burma Library">[http://www.burmalibrary.org/reg.burma/archives/199507/msg00263.html Burma Library website]</ref><ref name="Landmark Declarations from Burma Lawyers' Council">[http://www.blc-burma.org/html/Declaration%20treaty%20agreements/bsdeclara2.html Burma Lawyers' Council characterizes Declarations as Landmark]</ref>
===Bommersvik Declaration I=== In 1995, during the first convention that lasted from 16–23 July, the [[National Coalition Government of the Union of Burma|Representatives]] issued the ''Bommersvik [[Declaration of independence|Declaration]] I'' with the following preamble:<ref name="Bommersvik Declaration from NCGUB website">{{Cite web |url=http://www.ncgub.net/staticpages/index.php/Bommersvik_Declaration_1995# |title=Bommersvik Declaration from NCGUB website |access-date=1 October 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928070916/http://www.ncgub.net/staticpages/index.php/Bommersvik_Declaration_1995# |archive-date=28 September 2007 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
{{quote|''We, the representatives of the people of Burma, elected in 27 May 1990 general elections, meeting at the First Convention of Elected Representatives from the liberated areas of Burma, hereby – Warmly welcome the unconditional release of 1991 [[Nobel Peace Prize|Nobel Peace laureate]] [[Aung San Suu Kyi|Daw Aung San Suu Kyi]] on 10 July 1995; Thank all who have worked tirelessly and consistently for the release of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and the cause of democracy in Burma; Applaud Daw Aung San Suu Kyi's determination, in spite of having spent 6 years under house arrest, to continue to work to bring true democracy to Burma; Welcome Daw Aung San Suu Kyi's return to politics to take up the mantle of her father, General [[Aung San]], in Burma's second struggle for independence;...''|The Elected Representatives of the Union of Burma}}
===Bommersvik Declaration II=== In 2002, during the second convention that lasted from 25 February to 1 March, the Representatives issued the ''Bommersvik Declaration II'' with the following introduction:<ref name="Bommersvik Declaration ΙΙ from NCGUB website">{{Cite web |url=http://www.ncgub.net/staticpages/index.php/Bommersvik_Declaration_2002# |title=Bommersvik Declaration ΙΙ from NCGUB website |access-date=1 October 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928070823/http://www.ncgub.net/staticpages/index.php/Bommersvik_Declaration_2002# |archive-date=28 September 2007 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
{{quote|''We, the representatives of the people of Burma, elected in 27 May 1990 general elections presently serving as members of the National Coalition Government of the Union of Burma and/or the members of parliament Union, meeting at the Convention of Elected Representatives held in Bommersvik for the second time, hereby reaffirm – Our Mandate, Position, and Strategic Objectives – that we will never ignore the will of the Burmese people expressed through the May 1990 general elections; – that the military's refusal to honor the election results does not in any way diminish the validity of these results.....''|The Elected Representatives of the Union of Burma}}
==Managers== [[Image:Arne Jones Katedral.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Arne Jones's Katedralen sculpture in [[Västertorp]], Sweden. The sculpture provided the model for the school logo]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox dancer | name = Boris Volkoff | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Boris Vladimirovich Baskakoff | birth_date = {{birth date|1900|04|24}} | birth_place = Schepotievo, Russia | death_date = {{death date and age|1974|03|11|1900|04|24}} | death_place = [[Toronto]], Canada | height = | occupation = Dancer, director, [[ballet master]] | years_active = | current_group = | former_groups = Volkoff Canadian Ballet | dances = | website = }}
{{Eastern Slavic name|Vladimirovich|Volkoff}} '''Boris Vladimirovich Volkoff''', {{Post-nominals|country=CAN|CM}} (born '''Boris Vladimirovich Baskakoff'''; April 24, 1900 – March 11, 1974) was a Canadian-Russian ballet dancer, director, choreographer and [[ballet master]]. After studying dance in [[Warsaw]] and Moscow he defected from Russia and eventually settled in [[Toronto]]. He created the Boris Volkoff School of Dance which trained ballet dancers, and the Boris Volkoff Ballet Company which is arguably considered the first [[ballet company]] in Canada. He gave his dancers and studio to the [[National Ballet of Canada]] to raise the profile of Canadian ballet. He regretted this decision and attempted to revive his company which ended in failure. He was appointed as a Member of the [[Order of Canada]] in 1973, one year before his death.
== Early life and dance career ==
Volkoff, birth name Boris Vladimirovich Baskakoff, was born on April 24, 1900, in Schepotievo, Russia.<ref name=CEBV>{{cite web | last =Crabb | first =Michael | title = Boris Vladimirovich Volkoff | website = The Canadian Encyclopedia| publisher =Historica Canada | date =January 28, 2014 | url = http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/boris-vladimirovich-volkoff/ | accessdate = June 16, 2015 }}</ref>
When he was nine Volkoff joined his brother Igor in [[Warsaw]] to dance and perform for the Russian Army. He alternated between using this birth name and performing using the last name Volkoff, his mother's family name.<ref name=CEBV />
Volkoff attended the [[Moscow State Academy of Choreography]] and later danced with Mordkin Ballet<ref name=CEBV /> and the Moscow State Youth Ballet.<ref name=ArtsAlive>{{cite web | title = Boris Volkoff | website = Arts Alive| publisher =National Arts Centre | url = http://artsalive.ca/en/dan/meet/bios/artistDetail.asp?artistID=77 | accessdate = June 19, 2015 }}</ref> During a Siberian tour Volkoff defected from Russia and went to Shanghai.<ref name=CEBV /> He joined the Shanghai Variety Ballet<ref name=ArtsAlive /> and toured with Russian expatriates to various Asian countries and the United States. He danced with [[Adolph Bolm]]'s company until his visa expired and Volkoff was smuggled into Canada in 1929. He became [[ballet master]] at Jack Arthur's Uptown Theatre in [[Toronto]] and choreographed short dances that were performed between films. It was during this time that he decided to use Volkoff as his stage name.<ref name=CEBV />
== Choreographic works in Toronto ==
In 1930 Volkoff opened the Boris Volkoff School of Dance, which operated until 1974.<ref name=Passion>{{cite book | last =Neufeld | first =James | title =Passion to Dance: The National Ballet of Canada | publisher =Dundurn | date =2011 | location =Toronto | pages = | url =https://books.google.ca/books?id=9Eq7mIUeOh4C&printsec=frontcover | isbn =1-4597-0122-4 }}</ref> In 1932 he created ice ballet versions of [[Swan Lake]] and [[Prince Igor]] with the [[Toronto Skating Club]].<ref name=ArtsAlive /> He continued creating works for the club for fourteen seasons.<ref name=CEBV />
Volkoff brought his dance troupe to the [[1936 Summer Olympics]] to compete in an international dance competition.<ref name=Eyes>{{cite book | last =MacDonald | first =David B. | last2=DeCoste | first2=Mary-Michelle | title =Europe in Its Own Eyes, Europe in the Eyes of the Other | publisher =Wilfrid Laurier University Press | date =April 23, 2014 | location = | pages =322 | url =https://books.google.ca/books?id=16fmAwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover| isbn =1-55458-867-7}}</ref> His company performed two new ballets called ''Mon-Ka-Ta'' and ''Mala'', both based on [[Inuit]] and [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] legends.<ref name=CEBV /> The pieces were given five "honourable mentions".<ref name=ArtsAlive />
In 1938 the troupe that traveled to [[Berlin]] became the Volkoff Canadian Ballet, and later the Boris Volkoff Ballet Company. This company is sometimes considered the first Canadian ballet company.<ref name=ArtsAlive /> The company performed in many notable venues such as [[Massey Hall]] in 1939.<ref name=CEBV /> Volkoff co-founded the [[Canadian Ballet Festival]] with [[Gweneth Lloyd]] in 1948 to showcase the talent of Canadian ballet dancers<ref name=Heritage>{{cite web | last =Duggan | first =Brittany | title = Father of Canadian ballet commemorated with historic plaque| website = The Dance Current | date =January 7, 2010 | url = http://www.thedancecurrent.com/news-article/father-canadian-ballet-commemorated-historic-plaque| accessdate = May 25, 2015 }}</ref> and Volkoff Canadian Ballet was one of three companies to perform at its inaugural event.<ref name=ArtsAlive />
On March 2, 1949, Volkoff premiered ''The Red Ear of Corn,'' a ballet in two acts. The name refers to red ears of corn found in northern [[Quebec]] by huskers. The piece was inspired by Native American and [[French-Canadian music|French Canadian dance music]]. The musical score was composed by [[John Weinzweig]].<ref name=CERed>{{cite web | last =Morey | first =Carl | title = Red Ear of Corn | website = The Canadian Encyclopedia| publisher =Historica Canada | date =November 13, 2012 | url = http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/red-ear-of-corn-emc/ | accessdate = June 16, 2015 }}</ref>
== National Ballet of Canada ==
Unable to secure stable funding for the Volkoff Canadian Ballet<ref name=CEBV /> Volkoff worked with other Canadian ballet enthusiasts to create the [[National Ballet of Canada]]. Volkoff and [[Gweneth Lloyd]] both wanted to run the new company but they reached a compromise by bringing [[Celia Franca]] to be its new artistic director. Volkoff became the company's first resident choreographer.<ref name=Passion />
Volkoff gave his studio and dancers to the National Ballet and taught the male dancers of the company.<ref name=Passion /> He regretted this decision as he disliked [[Celia Franca]]'s "English" dancing style and believed ballet should be performed in the Russian style.<ref name=CEBV />
In 1952 Volkoff and [[David Adams (dancer)|David Adams]] created Toronto Theatre Ballet and became co-artistic directors. The company featured many of the founding members of the National Ballet.<ref name=Passion /> He attempted to revive his company in 1953 and 1967 but these ended in failure.<ref name=CEBV />
== Personal life ==
Volkoff married Janet Baldwin, a student at his ballet studio. She became his business associate in the operation of his studio.<ref name=Passion />
== Death ==
Volkoff died March 11, 1974, in Toronto.<ref name=CEBV />
== Awards ==
Volkoff was appointed as a Member of the [[Order of Canada]] in 1973.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gg.ca/honour.aspx?id=2343&t=12&ln=Volkoff|title=Order of Canada citation}}</ref>
In 2009 [[Heritage Toronto]] unveiled a plaque commemorating Volkoff. It was installed at the site of Volkoff's studio at 771 Yonge Street.<ref name=Heritage />

{{Infobox organization | motto = To expand access to high quality science education and to inspire and mentor the future generation of scientists and innovators through international scientific networks | type = Non-profit organization | volunteers = 50+ | name = Science Clubs | native_name = Clubes de Ciencia | abbreviation = CdeC | founding_location = Boston, MA | website = www.clubesdeciencia.org }}
'''Clubes de Ciencia'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.clubesdeciencia.org|title=Clubes de Ciencia Latin America – Clubes de Ciencia Latin America|website=www.clubesdeciencia.org|access-date=2016-06-23}}</ref> is a non-profit organization founded in 2014 that organizes hands-on week-long workshops in [[Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics|STEM]] to kids in developing countries at no cost.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.igeteomx.info/2014/07/seran-ug-y-cimat-sedes-de-los-clubes-de-ciencia/|title=Serán UG y CIMAT sedes de los Clubes de Ciencia|date=26 July 2014|language=es-ES|access-date=2016-06-23}}</ref> The instructors are PhD volunteers from top universities, such as [[Harvard University|Harvard]], [[Princeton University|Princeton]], [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] who organizes the workshops and mentor the students aiming at inspiring students to pursue their passions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eleconomista.com.mx/entretenimiento/2014/07/23/premia-harvard-clubes-ciencia-mexico|title=Premia Harvard a Clubes de Ciencia México|access-date=2016-06-23}}</ref> By combining hands-on experimental learning, on-line exercises and mentorship, Clubes de Ciencia takes a unique approach to educating the millennials in developing countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fundacionharvard.org/en/clubes-de-ciencias.php|title=Clubes-de-ciencias .: Fundación Harvard en México :.|last=Mecca|website=fundacionharvard.org|access-date=2016-06-23}}</ref> In two years, Clubes de Ciencia grew past its [[Mexico]] program, to also work in [[Colombia]] and [[Bolivia]]. Currently, it also operates in [[Brazil]], [[Paraguay]], [[Peru]] and [[Spain]]. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.elespectador.com/noticias/educacion/ninos-de-colegios-publicos-construyeron-microscopios-de-articulo-639307|title=Niños de colegios públicos construyeron microscopios de origami|access-date=2016-06-24}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=ATB Red Nacional|title=Clubes de Ciencia Bolivia estimulan a jóvenes a seguir carreras de ciencia y tecnología|date=5 January 2016|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ib4fXjcCTjs|accessdate=2016-06-24}}</ref>
== 2014 ==
The first edition of Science Clubs was organized in Guanajuato, Mexico, in January 2014,with the support of [[Universidad de Guanajuato]].<ref>{{Citation|last=ZonaFrancaMX|title=El Club de Ciencias México se realizará en Guanajuato y Ensenada|date=11 June 2014|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TormgV3D7Vg|accessdate=2016-06-23}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://zonafranca.mx/investigadores-imparten-talleres-en-clubes-de-ciencia-en-guanajuato/|title=Investigadores imparten talleres en Clubes de Ciencia en Guanajuato|date=16 January 2014|language=es-LA|access-date=2016-06-23}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gsas.harvard.edu/scholarly_life/spreading-the-science.php|title=Spreading the Science|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Harvard University – The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences|access-date=2016-06-23}}</ref> {{Quote|text="I always had really great science teachers, so I wanted to help give some of that back."|sign=Adrian Jinich|source=https://www.gsas.harvard.edu/scholarly_life/spreading-the-science.php}}{{Quote|text="We know we're privileged to be where we are, so we try to figure out ways to share that privilege"|sign=Rogelio Hernandez-Lopez|source=https://www.gsas.harvard.edu/scholarly_life/spreading-the-science.php}}
== 2017 ==
In 2017, Science Clubs expanded to three new countries: Paraguay, Peru and Brazil [http://www.scibr.org/clubes-de-ciencia-brasil/]
The first edition of the Brazilian Chapter ([https://www.clubesdeciencia.com.br Clubes de Ciência Brasil]) was held at [[Federal University of Minas Gerais|Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais]], in Belo Horizonte, in July 2017. Four clubs in the areas of [[epidemiology]], [[Stem cell|stem cells]] and [[genome editing|gene editing]], [[immunology]] and [[entrepreneurship]] were organized by researchers from top Universities from the US and Brazil, including Harvard, Northeastern and UFMG for 80 students from six different states of the country. <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://revistagalileu.globo.com/Ciencia/noticia/2017/07/brasileiros-de-harvard-criam-clube-para-ensinar-ciencia-jovens.html|title=Brasileiros de Harvard criam clube para ensinar ciência a jovens|work=revistagalileu.globo.com|access-date=2017-08-02}}</ref>
== Prizes and awards == On April 15, 2015, the Latin American Science Education Network (now Science Clubs International) was among the winners of the [[MIT]] "IDEAS" Global Challenge Awards.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Matheson|first1=Rob|title=“IDEAS” for social change|url=http://news.mit.edu/2015/ideas-global-challenge-0416|agency=MIT News Office|date=2015-04-16}}</ref>
Also in 2015, Mohammed Mostajo-Radji, as Executive Director of Clubes de Ciencia Bolivia was awarded the "Person of the Year" award by the Bolivian newspaper [[El Deber]] <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eldeber.com.bo/bolivia/deber-homenajea-11-personajes-del.html|title= El Deber homenajeo a 11 personajes del ano|website=eldeber.com.bo|access-date= 2016-09-03 }}</ref> and the [[Franz Tamayo]] Medal by the [[Senate of Bolivia]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://senado.gob.bo/prensa/noticias/senado-otorga-m%C3%A1ximas-condecoraciones-personalidades-e-instituciones-destacadas|title= Senado otorga maximas condecoraciones a personalidades e instituciones destacadas|website =senado.gob.bo|access-date=2016-09-03}}</ref>
In 2016, Hugo Arellano-Santoyo and Clubes de Ciencia were awarded with the Dean's Community Service Award from the [[Harvard Medical School]]. The prize is awarded "to recognize individuals whose dedication and commitment to community service have made a positive impact on the local, national, or international community".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mfdp.med.harvard.edu/awards/deanscommunityserviceaward|title=Dean's Community Service Award|access-date=2016-06-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://drclas.harvard.edu/news/hugo-arellano-santoro-and-clubes-de-ciencia-honored-hms-dean%E2%80%99s-community-service-award|title=Hugo Arellano-Santoro and Clubes de Ciencia honored with the HMS Dean's Community Service Award|website=drclas.harvard.edu|access-date=2016-06-24}}</ref>
In 2016, Maier Avendano, Executive Director of Clubes de Ciencia Colombia was named among the "Latino 30 under 30" by the [[El Mundo Boston]].<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2mDXZjIhNOM</ref><ref>http://www.latino30under30.com/maieravendano</ref> Mohammed Mostajo-Radji and the team of Clubes de Ciencia Bolivia received this award in 2017.
Additionally in 2016, Clubes de Ciencia Bolivia was awarded the Youth Peace Prize by the Government of Santa Cruz, Bolivia. <ref>{{cite news|last1=Redacción El Deber|title=Distinguen a 24 jóvenes sobresalientes|url=http://www.eldeber.com.bo/santacruz/Distinguen-a-24-jovenes-sobresalientes-20161220-0049.html|date=2016-12-20}}</ref>
In 2018, Clubes de Ciencia Bolivia received the Melchor Pinto Parada award from the Government of Santa Cruz <ref>{{cite web|last1=Avalos|first1=Beatriz|title=Legisladores condecoran a un colegio, una maestra y un científico|url=https://wp.eldeber.com.bo/santacruz/Legisladores-condecoran-a-un-colegio-una-maestra-y-un-cientifico-20180224-0006.html|website=El Deber|publisher=El Deber}}</ref>. This is the maximum award granted by this institution. Also in 2018, Omar Gandarilla, as Operations Director of Clubes de Ciencia Bolivia received the "Diversity in STEM" award from MiniPCR.
== Partners ==
The [[David Rockefeller Center for Latin American Studies]], the Department of Molecular and Cellular Biology at Harvard University,<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.mcb.harvard.edu/mcb/news/news-detail/3896/graduate-student-initiatives-science-club-latin-america/|title = Science Clubs Latin America Initiative|website=mcb.harvard.edu|access-date=2016-09-03}}</ref> the [[Harvard Stem Cell Institute]], COMEXUS and the Fundación México en Harvard University are among the key sponsors of the project.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kgi.edu/news-and-events/clubes-de-ciencia|title=As an instructor with Clubes de Ciencia, KGI PhD student Paola Hernandez hopes to get Mexican students thinking about a career in science and entrepreneurship|website=www.kgi.edu|access-date=2016-06-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://drclas.harvard.edu/event/conectados-al-sur-breakfast-ideas|title=Conectados al Sur – Breakfast of Ideas|website=drclas.harvard.edu|access-date=2016-06-24}}</ref>
== Endorsements ==
Clubes de Ciencia has been endorsed by a number of academics and celebrities, including 2004 Nobel Laureate [[Frank Wilczek]]; Margot Gill, Dean of International Affairs at [[Harvard University]] and [[Beakman]].

{{More citations needed|date=September 2009}} '''CollegeConfidential.com, Inc.''' ('''CC''') is a [[college]] admissions counseling company founded in 2001. It hosts popular [[College admissions in the United States|college admissions]] forums on topics such as admissions chances, [[Student financial aid (United States)|financial aid]], [[standardized testing]], and [[Higher education in the United States|school]] life.
==History== College Confidential was founded to "demystify many aspects of the college admissions process, and to help even 'first timer' students and parents understand the process." An editorial team, consisting of Dave Berry, a senior admissions officer, David Hawsey, and Roger Dooley, a parent who is active in high school academics, supply visitors with college admission content.<ref>[http://www.collegeconfidential.com/about.htm College Confidential - About] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120724014320/http://www.collegeconfidential.com/about.htm |date=2012-07-24}}</ref>
==College Confidential Forums== The College Confidential Forum represents the most heavily used part of the site. It features a very active 'What Are My Chances?' subforum, where users are evaluated on their chances of acceptance to specific colleges based on their test scores, [[Grade Point Average|GPA]], and [[extracurricular activities]]. There are also various other subforums regarding financial aid, [[SAT]], [[ACT (test)|ACT]] and [[Advanced Placement|AP]] test preparation, forums for all major colleges and universities, including those in the [[Ivy League]], as well as for the nation's top research universities and [[liberal arts college]]s.
==Media coverage== College Confidential was covered in a ''[[New York Times]]'' front-page story on March 31, 2006.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/31/education/31chatter.html |title=College Admission Angst Finds a Forum on Web |author=Susan Saulny |work=[[New York Times]] |date=March 31, 2006}}</ref> It has also been mentioned in a number of other press stories.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.collegeconfidential.com/press/inthenews.htm |title=In the News |publisher=College Confidential |accessdate=November 26, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20131127044558/http://www.collegeconfidential.com/press/inthenews.htm |archivedate=November 27, 2013}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of Internet forums]]

==External links== *{{Official website|name=College Confidential official website}}

'''David Dennis Buckingham''', {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|FBA|FAcSS}} (born 6 October 1954) is a media, communications and education scholar and retired academic.
== Career == David Dennis Buckingham was born on 6 October 1954. He completed his undergraduate studies at [[Clare College, Cambridge]], graduating in 1975. He worked at the [[Inner London Education Authority]] from 1978 to 1984, during which time he also completed film studies master's degree at the [[Polytechnic of Central London]] (in 1982). In 1984, he joined the [[UCL Institute of Education|Institute of Education]] as a lecturer, and completed a [[doctorate]] there in 1993 (awarded for his thesis "The development of television literacy: talk, text and context"). Three years later, he was promoted to a [[Reader (academic rank)|readership]] at the Institute, and in 1999 was promoted again to [[Professor (highest academic rank)|Professor]] of Education. He remained in that post until taking up a professorship at [[Loughborough University]] in 2012; he retired in 2014 and was appointed an emeritus fellow at Loughborough.<ref name="WhWaWh">[http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/10.1093/ww/9780199540884.001.0001/ww-9780199540884-e-284775 "Buckingham, Prof. David Dennis"], ''Who's Who'' (online edition, Oxford University Press, December 2017). Retrieved 28 June 2018.</ref><ref>[http://ethos.bl.uk/OrderDetails.do?did=8&uin=uk.bl.ethos.262077 "The development of television literacy: talk, text and context"], ''EthOS'' (British Library). Retrieved 28 June 2018.</ref>
According to his university profile, Buckingham specialises in "children's and young people's interactions with electronic media, and on media literacy education";<ref name="prof">[http://www.lboro.ac.uk/departments/socialsciences/staff/honorary/david-buckingham/ "Buckingham, David"], ''Loughborough University''. Retrieved 28 June 2018.</ref> his [[British Academy]] profile adds that he maintains interests in "media use, civic participation, consumerism, youth culture, sexuality, media literacy, media regulation, identity".<ref name="britac">[https://www.britac.ac.uk/users/professor-david-buckingham "Professor David Buckingham"], ''British Academy''. Retrieved 28 June 2018.</ref>
== Honours and awards == Buckingham was elected a [[Fellow of the Academy of Social Sciences]] (FAcSS) in 2011,<ref name="WhWaWh"/> and four years later he was also elected a [[Fellow of the British Academy]] (FBA), the United Kingdom's [[national academy]] of the humanities and social sciences.<ref name="britac"/>
== Selected publications == * (Editor) ''Reading Audiences: Young People and the Media'' (Manchester University Press, 1993). *''Children Talking Television: The Making of Television Literacy'' (Falmer, 1993). * ''Moving Images: Understanding Children's Emotional Responses to Television'' (Manchester University Press, 1996). * ''The Making of Citizens: Young People, News and Politics'' (Routledge, 2000). * ''After the Death of Childhood: Growing up in the Age of Electronic Media'' (Open University Press, 2000). * ''Media Education: Literacy, Learning and Contemporary Culture'' (Polity Press, 2003). * ''Beyond Technology: Children's Learning in the Age of Digital Culture'' (Wiley, 2007). *''The Material Child: Growing Up in Consumer Culture'' (Wiley, 2011). == References == {{Reflist}}
{{FBA 2015}}

'''Designated Special Character schools''' were created under the [[New Zealand]] Education Act of 1989[http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1989/0080/latest/DLM175959.html Education Act 1989] which allows the [[Ministry of Education (New Zealand)|Minister of Education]] to establish two types of special character schools under Sections 155 and 156 of the act. The Ministry of Education [https://www.education.govt.nz/school/running-a-school/managing-the-network-of-schools/changing-your-school-structure/becoming-a-section-156-designated-character-school/ defines a Designated Special Character School] as "a state school that has a particular character which sets it apart from ordinary state schools and kura kaupapa Māori. The only students who may enrol at a designated character school are those whose parents accept the particular character of the school." ==Section 155 schools== [[Kura Kaupapa Māori]] ([[Māori language|Māori-language]] immersion schools), where the principal language of instruction is [[Māori language|Māori]]. Kura Kaupapa Māori differ from the earlier [[Kohanga reo]] in that Kohanga reo are [[Language Immersion|immersion]] [[kindergartens]] whereas Kura Kaupapa Māori are immersion schools. * [[Te Kura o Waikare]] * [[Nga Taiatea Wharekura]] * [[Te Kura o Hirangi]] * [[Te Kura o Torere]] * [[Te Kura Toitu o Te Whaiti-nui-a-Toi]] * [[Te Kura Kaupapa Motuhake o Tawhiuau]] * [[Mana Tamariki]] * [[Te Kura o Te Whakatupuranga Rua Mano]] * [[Te Kura Maori o Porirua]] In 2018, some of New Zealand's twelve approved Partnership Schools (a version of charter school) successfully applied to become designated special character schools after the newly formed coalition government set about removing legislation from the New Zealand Education Act allowing for charter schools.http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PA1809/S00211/all-charter-schools-now-approved.htm ==Section 156 schools== These are identified as ''Designated Character Schools'', under Section 156.{{cite web|url=http://www.discoverylearning.co.nz/setting-up-state-school.html#156|title=Setting up a State School|last=unattributed|date=n.d.|publisher=unidentified|accessdate=2009-01-10}} The special character of schools established under this section is not specified in the Act, and parents may propose any desirable special character as long as no other local school is already delivering an education reflecting the same special character. * [[Discovery 1 School]]{{cite web|url=http://www.discovery1.school.nz/ |title=What is Discovery 1? |last=unattributed |date=2009 |publisher=Discovery 1 |accessdate=2009-01-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081228030559/http://www.discovery1.school.nz/ |archivedate=December 28, 2008 }} * [[Unlimited paenga tawhiti]] * [[Tamariki School]] * [[Te Whanau o Tupuranga]][https://www.gazette.govt.nz/notice/id/2010-go6930 ''"The merged school will be a Year 7-13 designated character school under section 156"''], 9SEP2010, gazette.govt.nz ==References==

{{Refimprove|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox dot-com company | name = Docsity.com | logo = File:Docsity Logo.png |company_type = [[Private company|Private]] | foundation = [[Turin]], Italy
(Jan 2010) | location = Turin, Italy | key_people = Riccardo Ocleppo ([[CEO]], Founder) | services = Social reading, publishing and sharing platform | revenue = | num_employees = | url = http://www.docsity.com | screenshot = | caption = | website_type = [[Social learning (social pedagogy)]] | language = English, Spanish, [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Serbian language|Serbian]], [[Russian language|Russian]], [[Polish language|Polish]] | launch_date = June 2011 | current_status = Active | alexa = {{Increase}} 36477 ({{as of|2013|4|3|alt=April 2013}}){{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/docsity.com |title= Docsity.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2013-04-03 }} }} '''Docsity''' is an online [[social learning (social pedagogy)|social learning]] network for worldwide students and professionals. Originally launched in 2010 exclusively for [[Italy|Italian]] students, it became an international website in mid-2012 by opening to worldwide students. It is advertisement-free and user-generated. Its features include document sharing, networking, news and blogs, video sharing, and a question and answer section. Docsity provides targeted content and user experience adaptations to users coming from Italy, United States, United Kingdom, [[Balkans]], Spain, [[South America]], Russia, [[Brazil]], [[Poland]], [[Portugal]] and [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] speaking countries. ==History== Docsity started as an initiative by two boys from [[Turin, Italy]] who were displeased by the amount of time a student had to spend on finding the correct study notes for any course. This was a very common issue with university and college students. Trying to address the problem, they started Docsity.com where students could share and view notes for free and also could discuss them with one another. The idea was greatly appreciated by the education community in Italy{{cite web|title=Facoltà DI CLICCARE|url=http://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/tecnologie/2010-06-10/facolta-cliccare-081400.shtml?uuid=AYA7IPxB&fromSearch|work=Il Sole 24 Ore|publisher=Il Sole 24 Ore|author=Marco Ferrando|language=Italian}} and later [[La Stampa]] called Docsity the fastest growing social network of students.{{cite web|title=Web mistress|url=http://www.lastampa.it/2011/09/16/torinosette/rubriche/web-mistress/web-mistress-PmNGIm2HWH7fdHCkxcOIhN/pagina.html|work=La Stampa|publisher=LaStampa|author=Alessandra C|location=Italy|language=Italian}} After the success in Italy it launched worldwide in June 2012. ==Features== * Document sharing: students can share their study notes and all their university-related documents for other students to search, view and download. * Networking: it help students to meet with other students through friendships, have fun studying, interact on each other's walls and get notifications on friends' activities. * News and Blogs: students can read various articles on everyday student life and become authors by submitting blog posts. * Video sharing: students can share and catalog academic videos from [[YouTube]] or upload their own videos for other students to view. * Q & A section: students from around the world can interact and help one another by answering questions and voting others contributions. Docsity has around 300,000+ study notes shared by students, 400,000+ Questions and Answers, 500+ published articles, 2,000+ academic videos and 500,000+ university students(Unofficial figures). ==Technology== Docsity allows its users to upload, download and share notes (including .doc, .pdf, .ppt and popular image formats). Its question and answer section allows students to ask and answer questions, and to vote, rate and comment on the answers. The video section offers videos catalogued or uploaded by students and can be searched by subject, course and type.{{cite web|title=Videos :Docsity.com|url=http://www.docsity.com/en/all-videos|work=Docsity.com}} The news and blog section contains news articles by university students on numerous topics related to education and everyday student life. The website offers a star rating and comments feature on all its content for the users for their feedback. These ratings are used to rank the content in the charts.{{clarify|date=April 2013}} Docsity allows users to post on walls, reply to comments, request friendships, search users from specific universities and areas of interest. The user base not only consists of students from universities and colleges, but also faculty members, company professionals and formal students.{{Citation needed|date=April 2013}} Docsity takes studying to a new social level, Study 2.0, the [[YouTube]] video{{cite web|title=Study 2.0, Move on with Docsity|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TZq6znxCPQ0|work=Youtube.com}} gives a visual introduction to all the features that Docsity offers. ==Points system== Docsity is free to use, but in order to increase the users' contributions it has a points management system.{{cite web|title=Points Management System|url=http://en.docsity.com/en/landing/share|work=Docsity.com}} Users are awarded points for sharing content and contributing to Docsity. These points are used to download content and gain a reputation on the website. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.docsity.com Official website] [[Category:Educational websites]]

'''Don't Filter Me''' is a project of the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] dedicated to fighting [[LGBT]]-related [[internet censorship]] that happens in [[State school#United States|public schools]] in the [[United States]].<ref name="dfm">{{cite web |url = https://www.aclu.org/dont-filter-me-web-content-filtering-schools |title = Don't Filter Me: Web Content Filtering in Schools |author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date = |website = aclu.org |publisher = [[American Civil Liberties Union]] |accessdate = 2014-12-14 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141215020503/https://www.aclu.org/dont-filter-me-web-content-filtering-schools |archivedate = 2014-12-15 |df = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |author = |authorlink = |coauthors = |date = |title = Don’t Filter MeFinal Report |url = https://www.aclu.org/files/assets/dont_filter_me-2012-1001-v04.pdf |publisher = [[American Civil Liberties Union]] |page = |docket = |format = PDF |accessdate = 2014-12-14 |quote = }}</ref><ref name="ars">{{cite news |last = Lasar |first = Matthew |title = “Don’t filter me”: ACLU fights schools that block LGBT websites |newspaper = [[Ars Technica]] |date = 2011-03-29 |url = https://arstechnica.com/business/2011/03/is-your-public-school-blocking-lgbt-websites-call-the-aclu/ |accessdate = 2014-12-14 }}</ref>
==History== State-funded schools in the United States use [[content-control software]] to restrict their students' access to pornographic websites, in accordance with the [[Children's Internet Protection Act]] of 2000.<ref name="fcc">{{cite web |url = http://www.fcc.gov/guides/childrens-internet-protection-act |title = Children's Internet Protection Act |author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date = 2014-07-16 |website = FCC.gov |publisher = [[Federal Communications Commission]] |accessdate = 2014-12-14 }}</ref> The products most commonly used to do this filtering treat websites that offer information about [[LGBT]] topics and organizations as pornography, even though these websites do not contain sexually explicit content.<ref name="dfm"/> One such commonly filtered website is [[The Trevor Project]],<ref name="makessense">{{cite news |last = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |first = |title = ACLU's 'Don't Filter Me' campaign makes sense |newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] |location = Los Angeles |date = 2011-09-08 |url = http://articles.latimes.com/2011/sep/08/opinion/la-ed-gaysites-20110908 |accessdate = 2014-12-14 }}</ref> a website devoted to suicide prevention among at-risk LGBT youths. The [[White House]] publicly praised the Trevor Project in 2011.<ref>{{cite news |last = Ring |first = Trudy |title = Trevor Project Honored at White House |newspaper = The Advocate |date = 2011-08-25 |url = http://www.advocate.com/news/daily-news/2011/08/25/trevor-project-honored-white-house |accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title = The Trevor Project |publisher = whitehouse.gov |date = 2011-08-25 |url = http://www.whitehouse.gov/champions/suicide-prevention/the-trevor-project |accessdate = 2014-12-14 }}</ref>
Other sites that are commonly blocked include [[GLAAD]],<ref name="nyt"/> [[PFLAG]] (Parents, Families and Friends of Lesbians and Gays), the [[Gay, Lesbian and Straight Education Network]] (also honored by the White House),<ref name="makessense"/><ref>{{cite news |last = Ring |first = Trudy |title = White House Honors GLSEN |newspaper = The Advocate |date = 2011-08-31 |url = http://www.advocate.com/news/daily-news/2011/08/31/white-house-honors-glsen |accessdate = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title = Gay, Lesbian & Straight Education Network |publisher = whitehouse.gov |date = 2011-08-31 |url = http://www.whitehouse.gov/champions/suicide-prevention/GLSEN |accessdate = 2014-12-14 }}</ref> the [[Matthew Shepard Foundation]], [[DignityUSA]],<ref name="judgeslaps">{{cite news |last = Harris |first = Joe |title = Judge Slaps School for Blocking Gay Websites |newspaper = Courthouse News Service |date = 2012-02-21 |url = http://www.courthousenews.com/2012/02/21/44029.htm |accessdate = }}</ref> [[Day of Silence]],<ref name="eschool"/> [[Campus Pride]],<ref>{{cite news |last = Berger |first = Judson |title = ACLU Sues Missouri School System for Censoring Gay Advocacy Websites |newspaper = [[Fox News Channel]] |date = 2011-08-16 |url = http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2011/08/16/aclu-sues-missouri-school-system-for-censoring-gay-advocacy-websites/ |accessdate = 2014-12-14 }}</ref> as well as the [[Human Rights Campaign]] (the largest LGBT civil rights advocacy group and political lobbying organization in the United States).<ref>{{cite news |last = Fenston |first = Jacob |title = ACLU Targets Camdenton Over LGBT Sites |newspaper = [[KBIA]] |date = 2011-09-26 |url = http://kbia.org/post/aclu-targets-camdenton-over-lgbt-sites |accessdate = }}</ref>
A student attempting to access these sites is usually confronted by a page warning, "You have been denied access as it is characterized as LBGT. Your Internet usage is monitored and logged."<ref name="ars"/>
Some [[Conservatism in the United States|American conservatives]] are supportive of blocks on these and similar websites since they consider them to be promoting the so-called "[[homosexual agenda]]".<ref name="makessense"/>
Filtering tools prevent that students from accessing websites related to positive LGBT organizations often permit access to sites that promote an anti-LGBT viewpoint, sites aimed at convincing LGBT people to change their sexual orientation, or sites that can be considered [[hate speech]] against LGBT people. Websites not generally blocked by this kind of filtering include the [[Family Research Council]] (an American conservative Christian group and lobbying organization), and the [[National Organization for Marriage]] (a political organization dedicated to working against the legalization of same-sex marriage in the United States),<ref name="makessense"/> [[Exodus International]], and [[People Can Change]] (both of which advocate [[conversion therapy]] to help gays change their sexual orientation).<ref name="nyt">{{cite news |last = Winerip |first = Michael |title = School District Told to Replace Web Filter Blocking Pro-Gay Sites |newspaper = [[New York Times]] |location = New York City |date = 2012-03-26 |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/26/education/missouri-school-district-questioned-over-anti-gay-web-filter.html |accessdate = 2014-12-14 }}</ref> Neither the [[American Psychiatric Association]] or the [[American Psychological Association]] consider [[conversion therapy]] a legitimate medical practice or homosexuality to be a [[mental disorder]].<ref>{{cite book |title = Covering: The Hidden Assault on Our Civil Rights |last = Yoshino |date = 2011-11-02 |publisher = Random House |isbn = 978-0375760211 |chapter = Gay Conversion |quote = Today, conversion therapy grows scarce. The major mental health associations, such as the American Psychiatric Association and the American Psychological Association, have withdrawn their support for the practice. |first1 = Kenji |authorlink = Kenji Yoshino }}<!--|accessdate=2014-12-15 --></ref> <ref>{{cite book |title = Covering: The Hidden Assault on Our Civil Rights |last = Yoshino |date = 2011-11-02 |publisher = Random House |isbn = 9780375760211 |chapter = Gay Conversion |quote = The efforts of these activists, along with their allies within the psychiatric establishment, led to the deletion of homosexuality from the DSM on December 15, 1973. |first1 = Kenji |authorlink = Kenji Yoshino }}<!--|accessdate=2014-12-15 --></ref>
Companies that filter content for schools often include anti-LGBT content in their "religion" category.<ref name="judgeslaps"/>
Filtering software can also block content beyond the websites themselves. Students would, for example, be permitted to read [[Bowers v. Hardwick]], the 1986 [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] decision that upheld a Georgia law to criminalize sodomy, while prevented from reading [[Lawrence v. Texas]], the 2003 Supreme Court ruling that asserted [[sodomy law]]s were unconstitutional.<ref name="nyt"/> The [[American Civil Liberties Union|ACLU]] contends that this filtering is discriminatory and violates the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] rights of students in public schools.<ref name="dfm"/>
In February 2011, the ACLU launched the ''Don't Filter Me'' project, to combat this censorship and discrimination in viewpoint that was happening in state-funded schools.<ref name="dfm"/>
==Response== Because of the Don't Filter Me project's efforts, some software providers who sell these filters implemented changes in their products. Companies such as [[Lightspeed Systems]] and [[Fortinet]] took action on their own and changed how their products categorize the websites in question.<ref name="eschool">{{cite news |last = Zwang |first = Jenna |title = Companies respond to ACLU’s ‘Don’t Filter Me’ campaign |newspaper = eSchool News |date = 2011-06-16 |url = http://www.eschoolnews.com/2011/06/16/companies-respond-to-aclus-dont-filter-me-campaign/ |accessdate = 2014-12-14 }}</ref> A number of school districts took steps to unblock LGBT-themed content that is not sexually explicit. The [[Rowland Unified School District]] and [[Oroville Union High School District]] were among the first to take action because of the work of the Don't Filter Me project.<ref name="makessense"/>
Many other school districts followed suit and updated their filtering software to allow LGBT sites to be accessed from school computers.<ref>{{cite news |last = Quillen |first = Ian |title = ACLU Puts Pressure on Districts to Ease Internet Filtering |newspaper = [[Education Week]] |date = 2011-10-17 |url = http://www.edweek.org/dd/articles/2011/10/19/01filter.h05.html |accessdate = 2014-12-14 }}</ref> Conservative Christian groups like [[Alliance Defending Freedom]] urged school districts not to comply with the ACLU's requests.<ref>{{cite news |last = Wetzstein |first = Cheryl |title = ACLU battles schools over gay websites |newspaper = [[Washington Times]] |location = Washington, DC |date = 2011-08-29 |url = http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/aug/29/aclu-battles-schools-over-gay-websites/ |accessdate = 2014-12-14 }}</ref>
In August 2011 the ACLU sued the Camdenton R-III School District of [[Camden County, Missouri]], which had refused to change its filtering software, or the filtering behavior that that software created. This led a federal judge to issue a [[preliminary injunction]] to the district, ordering it to stop using software produced by the company [http://urlblacklist.com/ URL Blacklist] that blocks access to sites discussing LGBT issues. In her decision, Judge [[Nanette Kay Laughrey]] wrote "URL Blacklist systematically allows access to websites expressing a negative viewpoint toward LGBT individuals by categorizing them as 'religion', but filters out positive viewpoints toward LGBT issues by categorizing them as 'sexuality'."<ref name="judgeslaps"/> The school district later settled, and agreed to stop blocking the sites in question, to be monitored for 18 months, and to pay $125,000 in fines and court costs.<ref>{{cite news |last = KRMS News |title = ACLU: “Surprised” Camdenton Schools Agreed to Settle |newspaper = [[KRMS]] |date = 2012-03-29 |url = http://www.krmsradio.com/aclu-suprised-camdenton-school-districts-agreed-to-settle/ |accessdate = 2014-12-14 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last = Associated Press |title = Camdenton school district agrees to settlement with ACLU |newspaper = [[KBIA]] |date = 2012-03-29 |url = http://kbia.org/post/camdenton-school-district-agrees-settlement-aclu |accessdate = 2014-12-14 }}</ref>
{{Portal|Freedom of speech}}
==External links== * [https://www.aclu.org/secure/dont-filter-me-students-check-your-schools-web-filter Don't Filter Me form to report your school's web filter]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
